(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-06-30 06:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-06-30 15:57:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm OK with the general direction of this spec.

There's a question inline.

Here's a general observation.  I don't think you should mention Cinder backends at all in this spec.  Cinder doesn't expose backends to users and it doesn't expose them to Glance, either.  What you get are volume_types.  A single volume_type may correspond to one or more Cinder backends, the user doesn't really know unless the operator chooses to expose this info.  Also, there could be multiple volume types all using the same backend; the difference could be that one volume_type specifies that the volume must be replicated, or must be stored in a particular AZ, or something like that.  The glance admin can only work with the volume_types that have been configured by the cinder admin.  I think this is an important distinction, because it *could* be possible for cinder to offer glance some kind of special pass-through so that it can store images in a particular backend--but that's not what we're talking about here, and we don't want operators to get the wrong impression of what this glance feature can do.

So, just as we try to always do with glance stores (i.e., not expose the actual backend technology in the store name or description), I think you should use more neutral names for the cinder volume types (e.g., instead of 'lvmdriver-1' use 'volume-type-A').  But don't mention cinder backends at all."}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2020-07-01 06:33:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I'm OK with the general direction of this spec.
 > 
 > There's a question inline.
 > 
 > Here's a general observation.  I don't think you should mention
 > Cinder backends at all in this spec.  Cinder doesn't expose
 > backends to users and it doesn't expose them to Glance, either. 
 > What you get are volume_types.  A single volume_type may correspond
 > to one or more Cinder backends, the user doesn't really know unless
 > the operator chooses to expose this info.  Also, there could be
 > multiple volume types all using the same backend; the difference
 > could be that one volume_type specifies that the volume must be
 > replicated, or must be stored in a particular AZ, or something like
 > that.  The glance admin can only work with the volume_types that
 > have been configured by the cinder admin.  I think this is an
 > important distinction, because it *could* be possible for cinder to
 > offer glance some kind of special pass-through so that it can store
 > images in a particular backend--but that's not what we're talking
 > about here, and we don't want operators to get the wrong impression
 > of what this glance feature can do.
 > 
 > So, just as we try to always do with glance stores (i.e., not
 > expose the actual backend technology in the store name or
 > description), I think you should use more neutral names for the
 > cinder volume types (e.g., instead of 'lvmdriver-1' use
 > 'volume-type-A').  But don't mention cinder backends at all.

I've some thoughts regarding this.
Generally the volume types on cinder side are configured as lvmdriver-1, nfsdriver-1 etc. so this seems ok.
Also this is the only link between glance_store and cinder so apart from the volume type, we don't have any other way of knowing in which backend the volume will actually be created.
IMO The admins will be well aware regarding cinder types and backends to match with each store.
And i think it is OK to use backend/driver incase of a spec and we can rephrase this in the operator documentation ?
Having said that, i think what you want to point out is if we configure a glance_store as FAST then we should also configure a corresponding FAST volume type linking to a fast backend and configure it here? i guess that is also feasible."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-01 11:09:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> I've some thoughts regarding this.
 > Generally the volume types on cinder side are configured as
 > lvmdriver-1, nfsdriver-1 etc. so this seems ok.

I have to strongly disagree with that statement.

Most service providers do not want any backend information leaked to their users. So in most deployments I've seen, the volume type most definitely did not include the type of storage that the type is using. In fact, in several cases there is no specific backend for a volume type (i.e. they don't set backend name in the extra specs) and just let the scheduler pick the appropriate backend based on the characteristics defined for the type. This is kind of the whole point of having volume types.

 > Also this is the only link between glance_store and cinder so apart
 > from the volume type, we don't have any other way of knowing in
 > which backend the volume will actually be created.

You don't. An outside consumer, whether that be an end user, and admin, or another service, will never be able to know for certain which backend the volume will be created on in all cases.

 > IMO The admins will be well aware regarding cinder types and
 > backends to match with each store.
 > And i think it is OK to use backend/driver incase of a spec and we
 > can rephrase this in the operator documentation ?

I agree with Brian here - we should not reference Cinder backends anywhere here, because outside of the internals of Cinder, they do not exist."}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2020-07-04 06:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> > I've some thoughts regarding this.
 > > Generally the volume types on cinder side are configured as
 > > lvmdriver-1, nfsdriver-1 etc. so this seems ok.
 > 
 > I have to strongly disagree with that statement.
 > 
 > Most service providers do not want any backend information leaked
 > to their users. So in most deployments I've seen, the volume type
 > most definitely did not include the type of storage that the type
 > is using. In fact, in several cases there is no specific backend
 > for a volume type (i.e. they don't set backend name in the extra
 > specs) and just let the scheduler pick the appropriate backend
 > based on the characteristics defined for the type. This is kind of
 > the whole point of having volume types.
 > 

In an ideal case that would be true and is really important for security purpose but In practical deployments, I've mostly seen them using the volume types similar to backend names to have convenience of knowing in which backend their volume would be created. 

 > > Also this is the only link between glance_store and cinder so
 > apart
 > > from the volume type, we don't have any other way of knowing in
 > > which backend the volume will actually be created.
 > 
 > You don't. An outside consumer, whether that be an end user, and
 > admin, or another service, will never be able to know for certain
 > which backend the volume will be created on in all cases.
 > 

That way an admin would need to know if volume type RELIABLE points to ceph or netapp or any other backend, that's the only inconvenience here.

 > > IMO The admins will be well aware regarding cinder types and
 > > backends to match with each store.
 > > And i think it is OK to use backend/driver incase of a spec and
 > we
 > > can rephrase this in the operator documentation ?
 > 
 > I agree with Brian here - we should not reference Cinder backends
 > anywhere here, because outside of the internals of Cinder, they do
 > not exist.

I have no issue with Brian's changes here, i just shared the scenario which I've seen seen in deployments."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-07-06 05:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-07-06 05:20:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Catch keystone InternalServerError in try

Add keystoneauth1.exceptions.http.InternalServerError to exceptions
caught gracefully when setting up Octiva during deploy time.

Change-Id: I100cb1cfbff0b764932acccb0fdbb76ce6d1715c
Closes-Bug: #1818113

Introduce scope_types in hosts policy

Appropriate scope_type for nova case:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-08-05 08:43:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix neutron_sanity_check for ML2/OVS overcloud

Previously validator failed running on neutron_api as the
neutron-sanity-check binary requires additional capabilities, causing it
to alway fail [0]. In addition, in some cases a race condition in
oslo_privsep can cause the validator to hang indefinitely [1].

This fixes it if the overcloud uses ML2/OVS, using the neutron_ovs_agent
container as we already did on the undercloud, and skipping the check if
it cannot be found (ML2/OVN deployments typically).

Additional fixes to the validator:
* skip gather_facts step
* fix output parsing
* call neutron-sanity-check only once, with all configuration files
  passed to it
* drop redundant default values in playbook itself

[0] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1783195
[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1862364

Change-Id: Ifacbbd6a493019e606105f45f0302bf1a88bed62
Co-Authored-By: CÃ©dric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3561628f2aac62f27ba6f6f97f814366be7e8993)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix neutron_sanity_check for ML2/OVS overcloud

Previously validator failed running on neutron_api as the
neutron-sanity-check binary requires additional capabilities, causing it
to alway fail [0]. In addition, in some cases a race condition in
oslo_privsep can cause the validator to hang indefinitely [1].

This fixes it if the overcloud uses ML2/OVS, using the neutron_ovs_agent
container as we already did on the undercloud, and skipping the check if
it cannot be found (ML2/OVN deployments typically).

Additional fixes to the validator:
* skip gather_facts step
* fix output parsing
* call neutron-sanity-check only once, with all configuration files
  passed to it
* drop redundant default values in playbook itself

[0] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1783195
[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1862364

Change-Id: Ifacbbd6a493019e606105f45f0302bf1a88bed62
Co-Authored-By: CÃ©dric Jeanneret <cjeanner@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3561628f2aac62f27ba6f6f97f814366be7e8993)

[{'created': '2020-07-25 03:08:31.000000000', 'message': "Add test coverage of hosts policies

Current tests do not have good test coverage of existing policies.
Either tests for policies do not exist or if they exist then they
do not cover the actual negative and positive testing.

To adopt the keystone's scope_type and new defaults in deprecated
API policies, we need to first write test coverage for the same to
know the complete effect of policies changes.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-deprecated-apis

Change-Id: Id398dfc2edaf75e60e2a3df48c478e2646a2a06e
"}]
commit_message:
Add test coverage of hosts policies

Current tests do not have good test coverage of existing policies.
Either tests for policies do not exist or if they exist then they
do not cover the actual negative and positive testing.

To adopt the keystone's scope_type and new defaults in deprecated
API policies, we need to first write test coverage for the same to
know the complete effect of policies changes.

Partial implement blueprint policy-defaults-refresh-deprecated-apis

Change-Id: Id398dfc2edaf75e60e2a3df48c478e2646a2a06e

commit_message:
RBD: Cleanup temporary file during exception

During copy image to encrypted volume operation, we create a
temporary image file to convert source image into an encrypted
image and rename it to source image name.
If any error occurs during this process, there is no code to
cleanup the temporary '.luks' file.
This patch adds the following cleanup.

Change-Id: I05dfc996a635299990fdafba841ab6c4fd7d32c7
Closes-Bug: 1873738
(cherry picked from commit 7c95f3969f4c0df5f818f96cb662dddc17a8dd6f)
(cherry picked from commit 02de7897d4e4ec3be6c4684a2e73a054956d1a00)
